design_principles.name: Simplicity
design_principles.definition: Simplicity is achieved by removing non-essential elements and reducing visual noise, leading to better usability.

techniques.name: Reduction
steps: Decide what must be conveyed by the design.
Remove any element that isn’t essential.
techniques.example: Google’s homepage removes all nonessential links to focus entirely on the search bar.

techniques.name: Combination
steps: Use UI elements that serve multiple purposes.
Leverage affordances that support multiple mental models (e.g., scroll thumb for position + navigation).
techniques.example: Scrollbars combine dragging, position indicator, and visible range feedback.

quotes: Simplicity is a process of elimination, not accretion.
Sketching many ideas helps prevent fixation on an early, suboptimal design.

references.text: Sketching User Experiences by Bill Buxton

example_analysis.title: Ghostview vs. Acrobat
example_analysis.summary: Ghostview and Acrobat use opposite scrolling metaphors, leading to potential confusion if used interchangeably.

example_analysis.title: FileMatrix vs. Google
example_analysis.summary: FileMatrix overloads users with complexity, whereas Google’s homepage exemplifies reduction and visual simplicity.
